content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Something like an initiation to the official puzzles Chuck Norris and Music scores.

Both the test case and validators for INVALID have the length discrepancies on the first and last rows. You would get slightly more coverage if at least one of them had a discrepancy on some row(s) in the middle of the input.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice for beginners !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment:

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Sympat
Le cas "INVALID" pimente l'exercice

I think this is very much possible to implement, the algorithm is simple enough. This would make a nice problem.

I have tested the solution in python everything looks fine. The problem statement is clear enough in my opinion

Took roughly between 10 to 12 minutes to implement it correctly

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Tried out test cases and looks good. Approved.

I would like to approve this simple puzzle but only for the statement is still unsatisfactory.

I tried taking the challenge to write the puzzle statement in an enlightening way. I found that describing how to encode is much easier than explaining how to decode. So instead of explaining the decoding procedure, you can provide the encode method and let coders discover the decoding method themselves.

In the experiment, I have already rewritten the whole statement. Pasted below for your ref or for copy n paste to use directly. You just need to touch up the styles again.

~~~~~~~~~~
You are going to write a simple program to decode some arrays of data into a black-and-write graphic.

The graphic is composed of N lines of black and white pixels. We use '0' to represent a white pixel; '1' to represent a black pixel.

For example, here is one line of graphic
00001110

We shall encode it into an array 4 3 1 
because it starts with 4 whites, then 3 blacks, then 1 white.
We assume most line shall start with white.

When there is a line starting with black, we add '0' at the beginning of the encoded data.

For example
11011111
will be encoded into 0 2 1 5

In this puzzle, you will be given N lines of encoded data.
You are going to decode it into a graphic.

=========
Input
First line : Integer N, number of rows in the graphic
N next lines : Each line is an array of integers, space separated, representing an encoded graphic line.

=========
Output
A valid graphic should be a rectangle. Write N lines of equal length strings to compose the graphic.
Use '0' to represent a white pixel; '1' to represent a black pixel.

In case the resulting graphic is not a rectangle, do not output the graphic. Output: INVALID

=========
Constraints
N < 200

I think this is easy enough to stay in Easy, but it could be difficult to immediately understanding the encoding/decoding method from your one sentence explanation, even with the aid of several examples.

Could improve it by giving a self-explaining example and have a short paragraph to explain how to decode it (if you target it at Easy). 

e.g. 3 lines:

3 1
2 2
0 2 2

I feel your several 1 and 0 Examples at the beginning are confusing more than convincing. I was wondering whether I am handling binary numbers or matrix. Besides, the very crucial guide about starting value is sadly hidden in Constraints. Should move it to the section explaining an example.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: make it medium and i'll think
I liked how simple this was. It's refreshing to have simple puzzles in the easy section that don't require you to know some kind of math trick or geometry to figure out.

Run-length encoding and variants already appear in several CoC (e.g. https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/335f6260ce0c10ceefd06ff4ad7b70c3b3) as well as the first step of this harder puzzle https://www.codingame.com/training/expert/music-scores
I don't think this is interesting & original enough for an easy puzzle.
The stub generator cannot handle reading an unknown number of ints per line. Have it read each line as a string instead.
I dont think that it is "Too easy" reasonable for an easy section
Its very easy add something else in it to make it bit tougher.
If you have any idea to improve this puzzle, I'd like to know it, thanks.

Reminds me of "Nonogram inversor" too
https://www.codingame.com/training/hard/nonogram-inversor
oh, do you think this is too hard ?!
Done, thank you for the advice
No, he meant he's not thinking yet, and will only start if you make it medium.

Yes, but it's quite different too. In a nonogram you only know the sizes of the blocks of 1s (both horizontally and vertically) and you have to recompute the sizes of the blocks of 0s (whenever possible/unique) to recover the image.
Here there is no missing information, simply a run-length encoding (the most basic lossless compression one can imagine) of each line.

That said, here is another example of a CoC based on RLE (and I'm sure there are more): https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/1868690a0b4371346c4573f9e7e83fc7c239
yep, agreed.
